detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: 310 is open to BA music majors or other students, if they have had two years of theory and MUSC 309.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Conducting courses MUSC 311, MUSC 312, and MUSC 313 are required for BMUS students majoring in GSEM, GSSM, and COMP. Other students interested in taking the course can sign up online to the waitlist. In late July, waitlisted students will receive an application form to fill out which includes rationale for taking the course.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Conducting courses MUSC 311, MUSC 312, and MUSC 313 are required for BMUS students majoring in GSEM, GSSM, and COMP. Other students interested in taking the course can sign up online to the waitlist. In late July, waitlisted students will receive an application form to fill out which includes rationale for taking the course.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: MUSC 319. Permission of the instructor is also required. Contact instructor to register.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: For Non-MUSC Majors.This course cannot count towards the BMUS or the BA Major or Minor in Music.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: In this course, we will learn about music used in video games, from the earliest beeps and bloops emitted by arcade cabinets to the cinematic scores of today's biggest franchises. This course blends history and analysis, taking inspiration from many existing pieces of scholarship written in the field of video game music studies, a.k.a. "ludomusicology." Students will learn about the composers and technological developments that facilitated some of the most memorable tunes from their childhoods, and will even get a chance to write some of their own music.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: This course offers a survey of the music of the Baroque era in Western Europe, covering roughly the period from 1600 to 1750. Sacred, secular, and instrumental repertories will be considered. While the course will present a broad cultural and social framework for understanding the music of the era, it will also examine selected compositions in greater analytical depth. Among the composers highlighted will be Monteverdi, Strozzi, Schtz, Lully, Purcell, Vivaldi, Rameau, Handel, and Bach.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
In this course you will be watching and analyzing contemporary Nordic film and will discover the multifaceted aspects of Nordic cinematic cultures. This region is often considered to rely on a very realistic (or even hyper-realistic) approach to filmmaking and storytelling, but it will become clear that there are some very unique directorial approaches which will broaden our expectations of what Nordic cinematography has to offer. Recognizable themes as social structures, gender equity, andenvironmental concerns will be highlighted.

Course blog here.

Interested in other courses within the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies? Click here.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Norse Mythology 

NORD 339 covers the basic components and features of Old Norse Mythology, including its cosmology, its position in the larger Germanic and Indo-European mythologies, its problematic relationship with Christianity, and its role in 19th-centuey nationalism, 20th-century racism and 21st-century popular culture.

Interested in other courses within the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies? Click here.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This survey course explores the diverse histories and cultures of Smi peoplethe Indigenous peoples of Norway, Sweden, Finland, and the Kola peninsula of Russia. From reindeer to religion, from folklore to Frozen II, this course examines Smi traditional culture, the impacts of settler colonialism upon it, and the ways revitalization and activism work as agents of decolonization today. This course meets the Place and Power requirement. 

Interested in other courses within the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies? Click here.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Pre-reqs: 6 credits each first year BIOL and CHEM; Year level 3, 4 or 5.
BEING ON THE WAITLIST DOES NOT GUARANTEE YOU A SPACE IN THE COURSE. Please do not contact course instructors or the department about registration issues; course registrations/waitlists are managed by the program office. The waitlist is managed by checking students meet the pre-requisites and chronologically checking the waitlist for the first student who can fit the course into their timetable. IF THERE IS A TIMETABLE CONFLICT YOU WILL NOT BE REGISTERED IN THE COURSE.
It is the student's responsibility to check for registration changes. Information on wait-list positioning will not be provided.

instances.text: PCTH_V 303-001 - Pharmacology in Health and Disease

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Course coordinator will register BSc PCTH students in the course. For non-PCTH students who are interested in the course, please write to course coordinator Dr. C.C.Y. Pang (ccypang@mail.ubc.ca) for enrolment.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: The co-op office will manually register students into co-op courses.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is a synchronous multi-access course. Students are expected to meet on the days and times listed, either in-person or online. All courses labelled multi-access offer students the choice of completing the course online, in-person, or using a mix of both. In-person attendance is NOT required, but the option to attend in-person is available. Lectures may be streamed from a classroom and/or uploaded online after class.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to Waitlist and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: This course will take place in the Pharmaceutical Sciences building, room 3340.

Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
